fullText: In "Wicked," the muddy $14 million spectacle that opened last night at the Gershwin Theatre, Chenoweth does what musical stars are expected to do in times of theatrical trouble: consult the book of spells, perform a bit of sorcery. This she accomplishes in spades as Glinda, the fabled good witch, promoted here from kitschy movie part to bravura stage lead. Whenever she opens her mouth - whether to demonstrate her supple coloratura or to detonate a verbal grenade or two - "Wicked" makes endearingly whimsical noises, the sounds of a bona fide crowd-pleaser. showScoreExcerpt:
"Wicked makes endearingly whimsical noises, the sounds of a bona fide crowd-pleaser. Much of the rest of the time, however, the magic fades as the show pursues its rather charmless agenda as a parable about the roots of political evil." 

Read more

keyPhrases.quote: Wicked makes endearingly whimsical noises, the sounds of a bona fide crowd-pleaser.

The mixed praise and criticism with no clear recommendation places this in the mixed category. | GPT-4o: The review praises Chenoweth's performance and some aspects of the show as a crowd-pleaser but criticizes the overall execution as lacking charm and magic. This suggests a mixed verdict with notable positive elements. | Gemini: The review praises Chenoweth's performance and calls the show a "bona fide crowd-pleaser," but also notes that "the magic fades" at times. This suggests a positive but not overwhelmingly enthusiastic recommendation. | Kimi: The review offers strong praise for Kristin Chenoweth's performance but criticizes the show overall as 'muddy' and 'charmless' with fading magic when she isn't on stage, resulting in a conflicted assessment.
